comment: Professor Joffe really cares about his students. He listens to student feedback and makes changes as needed. He is also clear about his grading rubric and always reminds the class about homework and test dates. These things made it easier to keep up and do well in the class.

He knows Physics so well and makes sure you understand the topic. He spend a lot of time derive equations and formula from scratch to make sure we understand why and what it is about. The test was pretty close to the homework questions and the curved.

I had him for physics II lab. If you show up, do the lab, and MAKE SURE TO HAVE THE RIGHT SIG FIGS, you will get an A. He is super caring and grades easy. If you have questions, he is more than willing to help. He is a great guy. He drops the lowest of the ten labs. Show up, do the work, you get an A.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Joffee is knowledgeable and supportive. However, during lectures, he covers a lot of material, and it can be hard to figure out what's most important. His test is hard, but he curves really high.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Accessible outside class

comment: Does a good job of turning very dense material into a lecture which is easier to understand. Physics I is a tough course for most people but Joffe does his best to simplify the material. You must attend Breakout and SI if want an A or B, especially if you have never had a physics course before. Calculus material is minimal.

Joffe was a great professor his lectures were clear. You mostly go through how to solve the problems in the breakout sessions. If you cannot attend your assigned breakout slot, you can show up to any, or all of them. The main issue comes down to pretty much the course difficulty. Make sure to attend both lecture and breakout. Don't skip it'll hurt

His lectures didn't really teach much you had to show up to the recitation to actually learn for the first time. Over the 50 minutes in lecture we would cover a very smallll amount of topics. He's a nice guy and makes jokes a lot but I wish the lectures would've been more informative rather than me having to teach myself through youtube videos.

Just a terrible teacher I have sat through weeks and weeks of lecture to learn absolutely zero things. Instead of teaching he just talks about nonsense that won't help us on the test. And his test have a 20 percent curve on them because so many people fail the tests . Do not take this Professor unless you wanna teach physics to yourself !

Just an "alright" professor. He's well-spoken and easy enough to follow, but his lectures aren't always super helpful. I did well by copying down formulas in class, working through online homework and breakout session problems (without attending the sessions), and making good cheat sheets, which he allows for tests.

For lab, SUPER EASY. Literally about all you have to do is show up, and you should get an A. Any time you have any question, just ask and he will answer. Usually you do that lab procedure during the time, and do calculations and report answers at home.

Physics isn't necessarily the easiest class to take or teach, and Joffe didn't help this at all. In class he teaches the theory of the subject, and the homework included nothing that was taught in class. He holds breakout sessions which are worth going to, but this class is nearly impossible. Take it with someone else!!!
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Joffe grades tests harshly. He curves after that to make up for it. His lectures focus on the theory and the breakout/study sessions focus on the problem solving. If you do not attend breakout, you will not do well on the tests.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: He is a great professor, his tests are very fair, and if you attend his study sessions you will do fine. He puts a heavy curve and does partial credit on all tests.

Professor Joffe gave a 20% boost to each test score for everyone. That may sound like a great thing but it really shows his ability to teach. He is not the worst physics professor however, he is not the best. He will give a very brief explanation of the topic and then ramble. Expect to learn physics on your own if you take him.

Never had a harder class in my life. If you are stuck with him, do the best you can and rely on the curve. The first test before the curve, there was: A: 1 B: 3 C: 26 F: 56 Let that sink in. His breakout sessions and homework problems are useless on the test. He manipulates it so bad to where you have no idea what you're doing. Worst teacher ever.

Joffe can get off on tangents about theory that are a waste of time. Breakout sessions are important, but still don't fully prepare you for exams. Webassign was busy work, but was part of your grade. Suggested problems helped a bit. Exams were curved quite a bit and still some people struggled.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Joffe is a bit of a mixed bag. Lectures are interesting but he really only presents the theory. His exams are almost entirely free response and require rigorous application of the theory to solve that not even the breakout sessions fully prepare you for. Webassign is a waste of time. Even with exam curves, many did not do well. Some extra credit.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Joffe is an amazing professor and a VERY fair grader. Pay close attention in break out sessions and homework questions. The formulas he gives you to prepare for a test should be taken literally when making your formula sheet. Also, know your calculus.

I failed Physics last semester with another professor and got a 100 on Prof. Joffe's first test. Not an easy class, but the fact that he can teach physics in a very direct way without making things complicated is what truly makes him stand out from all the other physics professors. By far my favorite professor I've taken so far. Highly recommend!

Hands down the best physics professor to take at KSU. Take him. Take him. Take him. Take him. I have a friend that is also taking physics with a different professor, and she is nearly failing. I have an A and haven't really struggled on anything in his class.

I took him in spring 2017. He's a great teacher. There were three tests and a final that were curved. The homework is 10% of your grade. And extra credit that could add a percent to your grade in the class. Also go to the breakout sessions because it is extra study material and could be on the test.
Best physics professor I've ever had. His homework is very helpful for studying.

Dr Joffe is nice guy and explains the content well, but so can the textbook. His tests are difficult and half the class fails most of the time. So all the good reviews below are misleading and either they are A+ students, because Joffe caters to the top 1% only. Take someone else, especially if you are doing multiple upper levels together.
The material is hard, but Dr. Joffe is more than willing to help in any way he can.  He offers office hours and extra study time.  I would rate him number 2 in the department behind Gully.

Dr. Joffe is a brilliant and gifted professor. He knows all the material and is able to teach is pretty well. The material is EXTREMELY difficult in Physics II and this isn't his fault. He makes is tests very fair, but grades them so that it's hard to fail, but hard to get an A. Do the HW, come to class, and STUDY HARD.

While the class material was difficult, Joffe makes this class better. Homework is a big part of your grade and he goes over the questions during class time - very helpful. Going to see him in his office is the best thing you can do if you're having trouble.

Dr. Joffe was an awesome professor. Sometimes his class notes were hard to understand and relate in his homework, but he cleared everything up in office hours. If it wasn't for office hours (the first I have ever gone to) I probably would have failed. It wasn't and easy class, but it is physics it isn't going to be easy. Overall fun and interesting

Awesome teacher. Really excited about Physics.  If you don't understand something TELL HIM. He's great about finding different ways to explain things. He grades very fairly (try ALL the problems- he will give you credit just for putting SOMETHING) He works really hard to make sure everyone is on the same page. Highly reccomend.

One of the best teachers ever.  On the younger side as far as a professor goes, so he 'gets' you. He's aware of undergraduate life, and does a very good job to accommodate hectic college life. He grades more than fairly. He is always available and willing to help. He explains material very well. He gives bonuses to let you replace blunders. _STUDY_
